newsitem.title: INDONESIA: INTERVIEW - Funds can defeat raiders with hybrids.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Funds can defeat raiders with hybrids.

text.p: Hybrid mutual funds are one of the best ways to fend off corporate raiders, a legal expert on mutual funds said on Tuesday.

"A closed-end fund is usually hampered by liquidity, which means it trades at a discount to net asset value and opens an avenue of attack to the mutual fund raider," Anthony Travers of law firm Maples and Calder told an industry conference in Jakarta.
"But a hybrid fund can offer the promise of liquidity and defuse the problem," he said.
Closed-end funds usually require investors to contribute at a fixed price and date for redemption or liquidation at a fixed future date.
Open-end funds start at a fixed price and date but receive period valuations of net asset value, allowing investors to move in and out at that price.
This requires liquidity in the fund or the power to borrow to meet redemption.
"It is a great mutual fund truth that if you cannot value accurately you cannot bring new investors in or let existing investors out which means you must have a closed-ended fund," Travers said.

Closed-end funds are suitable for venture capital or real estate projects where the assets are illiquid or difficult to value, he said. They were used extensively to finance the start-up of many Silicon Valley companies in the early 1980s.
But closed-end funds are increasingly at risk from mutual fund raiders who seek unit-holder support with promises of an immediate return on early liquidation.
"This is becoming more common," Travers said. "We have seen mutual fund raiders in Hong Kong, some of which have been successful."

Hong Kong's Regent Pacific Group Ltd, a mid-sized investment company, recently failed in its attempts to persuade shareholders in mutual fund Pioneer Industries International (Holdings) Ltd to sell its primary asset, a 3.77 percent stake in Bangkok Bank Ltd.
Regent, which owns 20 percent of Pioneer, is now seeking shareholder support to force the sale of various subsidiaries of Britain's Hambros Plc, in which Pioneer holds a three percent stake.
